prompt: Please generate an operative report for Dr. Dr. Chen. Patient is a 79 year old male with Persistent airleak. We performed therapeutic aspiration, BAL in the LUL (Apical-Posterior LB1+2) and RUL. We localized the leak to the RUL, placed sealant, and deployed Spiration valves in RB1 and RB2. Note that the first valve in RB2 was showed poor apposition and had to be exchanged.

NOTE_ID: note_021
SOURCE_FILE: note_021.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date]
INDICATION FOR OPERATION
[REDACTED] is a 79-year-old male who presents with Persistent airleak.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.

CONSENT
Obtained before the procedure. Its indications and potential complications and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate. The patient or surrogate read and signed the provided consent form / provided consent over the phone. The consent was witnessed by an assisting medical professional.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J93.9 Persistent airleak

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J93.9 Persistent airleak

PROCEDURE
Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode) (CPT 31645)
Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) (CPT 31624) – Done in multiple lobes
Bronchial valve insertion (initial lobe) (CPT 31647)
Balloon occlusion (CPT 31634)
Foreign body removal (valve removal/exchange) (CPT 31635)
Endobronchial sealant application

ATTENDING
Dr. Chen

ANESTHESIA
General Anesthesia

MONITORING
Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION
Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
None

COMPLICATIONS
None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL

General
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. Patient Position: Supine.

Therapeutic Aspiration
Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem from mucus and mucus plugs.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (First Site)
BAL was performed in the LUL (Apical-Posterior LB1+2) with saline instilled and returned. Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 30 cc of NS. Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (RUL)
BAL was performed in the Posterior Segment of RUL (RB2) with saline instilled and returned. Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 30 cc of NS. Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.

Bronchopleural Fistula (BPF) Localization and Occlusion
Serial occlusion with an endobronchial blocker (Arndt 7Fr) and Fogarty balloon was performed to isolate the airleak to the RUL (Apical and Posterior subsegment). The airleak was reproduced with inspiratory hold at 30 and suction on pleurovac on -10 cmH2O.

Endobronchial Sealant Application
Tisseel (1.5cc) was used to block off a subsegment of the RUL posterior branch.

Endobronchial Valve Placement and Exchange
Based on localization, Spiration valves were selected for deployment.

Attempt 1: A Size 7 Spiration valve was placed in RB2 but noted to be showed poor apposition; this was subsequently removed.

Placement: A Size 7 Spiration valve was placed in RB1 in good position.

Attempt 2: A Size 7 Spiration valve was placed in RB2 but noted to be in poor position; this was removed.

Placement: A replacement Size 7 Spiration valve was placed in RB2 in a better angle.

Final Valve Configuration:
RB1: Size 7 Spiration valve.
RB2: Size 7 Spiration valve.

Result
Airleak was significantly decreased following intervention. See Dr. Harrison's note for VATS and pleurodesis.

Conclusion
The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMENS
BAL (x2)

IMPRESSION / PLAN
[REDACTED] is a 79-year-old male who presents for bronchoscopy for BAL and valve placement.
Follow-up on BAL results.
Follow-up in 6 weeks for valve removal.

prompt: Create Op Report. CPTs: 31645, 31624 (BAL x2), 31647 (Valve initial), 31634 (Balloon), 31635 (Removal/Exchange). Dx: J93.82. Loc: RLL. Valve exchange required in RB10.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.

Obtained before the procedure. Its indications and potential complications and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate. J93.12 Prolonged post-op air leak

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J93.12 Prolonged post-op air leak

PROCEDURE
Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode) (CPT 31645)
Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) (CPT 31624) – Done in multiple lobes
Bronchial valve insertion (initial lobe) (CPT 31647)
Balloon occlusion (CPT 31634)
Foreign body removal (valve removal/exchange) (CPT 31635)
Endobronchial sealant application

ATTENDING
Dr. Ingraham

ANESTHESIA
General Anesthesia

MONITORING
Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION
Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
None

COMPLICATIONS
None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL

General
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. Patient Position: Supine.

Therapeutic Aspiration
Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem from mucus and mucus plugs.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (First Site)
BAL was performed in the RML (Medial Segment RB5) with saline instilled and returned. Instilled 50 cc of NS, suction returned with 30 cc of NS. Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (LLL)
BAL was performed in the Lateral-basal Segment of LLL (LB9) with saline instilled and returned. Instilled 50 cc of NS, suction returned with 30 cc of NS. Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.

Bronchopleural Fistula (BPF) Localization and Occlusion
Serial occlusion with an endobronchial blocker (Arndt 7Fr) and Fogarty balloon was performed to isolate the airleak to the LLL (Lateral and Posterior subsegment). The airleak was reproduced with inspiratory hold at 30 and suction on pleurovac on -15 cmH2O.

Endobronchial Sealant Application
Tisseel (2cc) was used to block off a subsegment of the LLL posterior branch.

Endobronchial Valve Placement and Exchange
Based on localization, Spiration valves were selected for deployment.

Attempt 1: A Size 9 Spiration valve was placed in LB10 but noted to be too large for the airway; this was subsequently removed.

Placement: A Size 7 Spiration valve was placed in LB9 in good position.

Attempt 2: A Size 7 Spiration valve was placed in LB10 but noted to be in poor position; this was removed.

Placement: A replacement Size 7 Spiration valve was placed in LB10 in a better angle.

Final Valve Configuration:
LB9: Size 7 Spiration valve.
LB10: Size 7 Spiration valve.

Result
Airleak was significantly decreased following intervention. See Dr. Thistlethwaite's note for VATS and pleurodesis.

Conclusion
The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

PROCEDURE
Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode) (CPT 31645)
Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) (CPT 31624) – Done in multiple lobes
Bronchial valve insertion (initial lobe) (CPT 31647)
Balloon occlusion (CPT 31634)
Foreign body removal (valve removal/exchange) (CPT 31635)
Endobronchial sealant application

ATTENDING
Dr. Miller

ANESTHESIA
General Anesthesia

MONITORING
Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION
Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
None

COMPLICATIONS
None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL

General
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location. Patient Position: Supine.

Therapeutic Aspiration
Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem from mucus and mucus plugs.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (First Site)
BAL was performed in the RML (Medial Segment RB5) with saline instilled and returned. Instilled 50 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS. Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (LLL)
BAL was performed in the Lateral-basal Segment of LLL (LB9) with saline instilled and returned. Instilled 50 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS. Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.

Bronchopleural Fistula (BPF) Localization and Occlusion
Serial occlusion with an endobronchial blocker (Arndt 7Fr) and Fogarty balloon was performed to isolate the airleak to the LLL (Lateral and Posterior subsegment). The airleak was reproduced with inspiratory hold at 30 and suction on pleurovac on -20 cmH2O.

Endobronchial Sealant Application
Tisseel (2cc) was used to block off a subsegment of the LLL posterior branch.

Endobronchial Valve Placement and Exchange
Based on localization, Spiration valves were selected for deployment.

Attempt 1: A Size 9 Spiration valve was placed in LB10 but noted to be showed poor apposition; this was subsequently removed.

Placement: A Size 5 Spiration valve was placed in LB9 in good position.

Attempt 2: A Size 5 Spiration valve was placed in LB10 but noted to be in poor position; this was removed.

Placement: A replacement Size 5 Spiration valve was placed in LB10 in a better angle.

Final Valve Configuration:
LB9: Size 5 Spiration valve.
LB10: Size 5 Spiration valve.

Result
Airleak was significantly decreased following intervention. See Dr. Thistlethwaite's note for VATS and pleurodesis.

Conclusion
The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
